document.docTitle: Osbornellus diamantinus Dominguez & Godoy 2010, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic review of the genus Osbornellus Ball (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae) in Central America 2702

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic review of the genus Osbornellus Ball (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae) in Central America 2702

heading.emphasis:
Osbornellus diamantinus Domínguez & Godoy
, sp. nov.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description. Length: 5.3–6.7 mm . Member of the
O. rarus
group ( Fig. 1b ). Vertex angulate, median length about equal to distance between eyes at posterior margin. General color yellowish. Face pale brown; wide dark band along anterior margin, interrupted by small pale spot, including ocelli, whitish diamond-shaped spot bordered by dark brown, with a white mark along coronal suture, rest of vertex mottled pale brown. Pronotum brown, mottled yellow-brown with irregular light and dark markings. Scutellum mottled yellowbrown with yellow at center, bordered with markings laterally, brown spot in basal angle margined with orange, posteriorly with white spot along each lateral margin. Anterior wing similar to other members of the species group.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 38.
Osbornellus diamantinus
sp. nov.
a) Pygofer. b) Valve and plate. c) Style. d) Aedeagus and connective, ventral view. e) Aedeagus, lateral view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis Externally very similar to
O. rarus
, but in lateral view the ventral processes of
O. diamantinus
are very narrow and shorter than the shaft. In
O. rarus
the ventral processes are thicker and similar in size to the shaft.
Distribution. Known only from Costa Rica ; 1100–2600 m .
Etymology. This species is named for the whitish diamond-shaped mark on the vertex.
